facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1954 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from Judgment and Decree dated 9th September 1952 of High Court of Bombay in Appeal No. 811 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 9th September, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 811 of 1951

facts.text: Original Decree from Judgment and Decree dated 24th July 1951 of Bombay City Civil Court in Suit No. 2310 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: from the Original Decree arising from the Judgment and Decree dated the 24th July, 1951, of the Bombay City Civil Court at Bombay in Suit No. 2310 of 1950.

facts.text: Suit instituted by appellant on a hundi for Rs. 10,000 dated 4th December 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted by the appellant on- a hundi for Re. 10,000 dated 4th December, 1947,

facts.text: Hundi drawn in favour of appellant by Haji Jethabhai Gokuil and Co. of Basra on respondents who are merchants and commission agents in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: drawn in his favour by Haji Jethabhai Gokuil and Co., Of Basra on the respondents, who are merchants and companymission agents in Bombay.

facts.text: Hundi sent by registered post to appellant in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The hundi was sent by registered post to the appellant in Bombay,

facts.text: Hundi received by Parikh Vrajlal Narandas who presented it to respondents on 10th December 1947 and received payment.

anchor.surface_text: and was actually received by one Parikh Vrajlal Narandas, who presented it to the respondents on 10th December, 1947, and received payment therefore

facts.text: Appellant doing business in forward contracts through Vrajlal as commission agent and residing at his Pedhi.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the appellant had been doing business in forward companytracts through Vrajlal as his companymission agent, and was actually residing at his Pedhi.

facts.text: Appellant sent notice to respondents on 12th January 1948 repudiating authority of Vrajlal and demanding return of hundi.

anchor.surface_text: On 12th January, 1948, the appellant sent a numberice to the respondents repudiating the authority of Vrajlal to act for him and demanding the return of the hundi,

facts.text: Respondents replied on 10th February 1948 denying liability, stating Vrajlal was agent and amount paid bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: to which they sent a reply on 10th February, 1948, denying their liability and stating that Vrajlal was the agent of the appellant, and that the amount was paid to him bonafide on his representation

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit on 9th December 1950 in Court of City Civil Judge Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th December, 1950, the appellant instituted the present suit in the Court of the City Civil Judge, Bombay.

facts.text: Plaint alleged payment to Vrajlal not binding on appellant, defendant-drawee remained liable on hundi.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint he merely alleged that the payment to Vrajlal was number binding on him, and that the defendant-drawee remained liable on the hundi.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded reliance on authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge and no cause of action as no averment of hundi acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, apart from relying on the authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge, also pleaded that the plaint did number disclose a cause of action against them, as there was numberaverment therein that the hundi had been accepted by them.

facts.text: Appellant gave evidence at trial that Vrajlal received registered cover containing hundi in his absence and collected amount without knowledge or authority.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, the appellant gave evidence that Vrajlal had received the registered companyer companytaining the hundi in his absence, and companylected the amount due thereunder without his knowledge or authority.

facts.text: City Civil Judge accepted appellant's evidence and held Vrajlal not authorised to receive amount.

anchor.surface_text: The learned City Civil Judge accepted this evidence, and held that Vrajlal had number been authorised to receive the amount of the hundi.

facts.text: City Civil Judge held plea of discharge by respondents implied hundi accepted by them and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: He also hold that the plea of discharge put forward by the respondents implied that the hundi had been accepted by them. In the result, he decreed the suit.

facts.text: Defendants appealed to High Court of Bombay, heard by Chagla C.J. and Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants took up the matter in appeal to the High Court of Bombay, and that was heard by Chagla C.J. and Shah J.

facts.text: High Court held no right of action unless hundi accepted, plaint no allegation of acceptance, no cause of action, allowed appeal and dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: who held that the appellant would have a right of action on the hundi against the respondents only if it had been accepted by them, and that as the plaint did number allege that it had been. accepted by them, there was numbercause of action. against them. They accordingly allowed the appeal, and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Plaintiff prefers appeal to Supreme Court on special leave under Article 136 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff prefers this appeal on special leave granted under article 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 28 May 1954 by Venkatarama Aiyar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. May 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-

facts.text: Vrajlal had no authority to receive payment according to City Civil Judge.

anchor.surface_text: held that Vrajlal had number been authorised to receive the amount of the hundi.

facts.text: Respondents paid hundi to Vrajlal on his representation of authority.

anchor.surface_text: and that the amount was paid to him bonafide on his representation that he was authorised to receive the payment.
The plaintiff prefers this appeal on special leave granted under article 136 of the Constitution.

Section 32 provides that, In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the maker of a promissory note and the acceptor before maturity of a bill of exchange are bound to pay the amount thereof at maturity according to the apparent tenor of the note or acceptance respectively, and the acceptor of a bill of exchange at or after maturity is bound to pay the amount thereof to the holder on demand.

concepts.interpretation: Under this section, the liability of the drawee arises only when he accepts the bill.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: here is numberacceptance, numbercause of action can

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Act that the drawee is as such liable on the instrument, the only exception being under section 31 in the case of a drawee of a cheque having sufficient funds of the customer in his hands and even then, the liability is only towards the drawer and not the payee.

concepts.interpretation: Exception for cheques, liability only to drawer not payee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 provides that, In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the maker of a promissory note and the acceptor before maturity of a bill of exchange are bound to pay the amount thereof at maturity according to the apparent tenor of the note or acceptance respectively, and the acceptor of a bill of exchange at or after maturity is bound to pay the amount thereof to the holder on demand.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill. In view of these provisions, there cannot be, apart from any mercantile usage, an oral accept- ance of the hundi, much less an acceptance by companyduct, where at least numberquestion of estoppel arises.

arguments.claim: Plea of discharge not equivalent to acceptance under s32.

holdings.text: The drawee of a negotiable instrument is not liable on it to the payee, unless he has accepted it. On the provisions of the Negotiable Instruments Act, no other conclusion is possible.

anchor.surface_text: that the drawee of a negotiable instrument is number liable on it to the payee, unless he has accepted it. On the provisions of the Negotiable Instruments Act, numberother companyclusion impossible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter III NI Act, esp s32, imposes liability on acceptor only; no privity without acceptance; cites s31 exception for cheques limited to drawer.

holdings.text: Section 61 does not limit presentment for acceptance to bills payable after sight; for demand bills, presentment for acceptance and payment synchronise, but acceptance is still required.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any substance in the companytention that section 61 of the Act provides for presentment for acceptance only when the bill is payable after sight, and number when it is payable on demand., as is the suit I.L.R, 3 Bo. 182 at P. 183. hundi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes stages for after-sight vs demand bills; acceptance necessary in both per NI Act; cites Ram Ravji.

holdings.text: There was no valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance as Vrajlal lacked authority to present or receive payment on behalf of the holder.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of the presentment of the hundi for acceptance, the position stands thus The person who presented it to the defendants was Vrajlal and if he had numberauthority to act in the matter, it is difficult to see how he companyld be held to have acted on behalf of the plaintiff in presenting the hundi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s78 requires payment to holder; lack of authority for payment means no authority for presentment; stages synchronise for demand bills.

holdings.text: The drawee becomes an acceptor only when he has signed his assent upon the bill; no oral acceptance or acceptance by conduct is valid.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill. In view of these provisions, there cannot be, apart from any mercantile usage, an oral accept- ance of the hundi, much less an acceptance by companyduct, where at least numberquestion of estoppel arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s7 codifies English Bills of Exchange Act s17; rejects verbal or implied acceptance; no estoppel issue.

holdings.text: Plea of discharge implies at best acknowledgment of liability, which is not sufficient to constitute acceptance under s32; acceptance must satisfy s7 requirements.

anchor.surface_text: Assume that the plea of discharge of a hundi implies an acknowledgment of liability thereunder-an assumption which we find it difficult to accept. The question still remains whether that is sufficient in law to fasten a liability on the defendants on the hundi. What is requisite for fixing the drawees with liability under section 32 is the acceptance by them of the instrument and number an acknowledgment of liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s32 requires acceptance, not mere acknowledgment; must be written and signed on bill per s7; rejects implication from plea.

holdings.text: In conclusion, there was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, nor a valid acceptance thereof.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion, we must hold that there was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, number a valid acceptance thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarises application of NI Act ss7,32,61,64,78 to facts: no authority for Vrajlal, no signed acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill. In view of these provisions, there cannot be, apart from any mercantile usage, an oral accept- ance of the hundi, much less an acceptance by companyduct, where at least numberquestion of estoppel arises.

anchor.surface_text: Assume that the plea of discharge of a hundi implies an acknowledgment of liability thereunder-an assumption which we find it difficult to accept. The question still remains whether that is sufficient in law to fasten a liability on the defendants on the hundi. What is requisite for fixing the drawees with liability under section 32 is the acceptance by them of the instrument and number an acknowledgment of liability.

Assume that the plea of discharge of a hundi implies an acknowledgment of liability thereunder-an assumption which we find it difficult to accept.
